title: How to Draw a Hawk

steps.headline: Create a slight downward curve that sharply cuts up again at the bottom.
steps.description: This is the left side of the face. Use sketchy, scratched lines for this.

steps.headline: Make a lower line for the bottom of the face.
Continue upwards with a slight outward curve.
steps.description: Reconnect the lines after a slight curve over the top.

steps.headline: Make a sharp V a little above the center of the head.
Draw a line that curves slowly at first, then drops away.
steps.description: Use the same scratchy technique that you used with the lower part of the hawk.

steps.headline: Add two dark holes on the top of either end of the beak.
Create an upside-down U over the holes and the beak, bringing a small line out from the right side of the beak.
Add a thick patch of lines along the right side.
steps.description: Have it slightly curve towards the beak.

steps.headline: Add two eyes on either side of the beak.
steps.description: Add a few details to the beak.

steps.headline: Create curving lines around the eyes and add a varying thickness to them.
steps.description: Then, on the left side, add some short thin lines to replicate tiny tufts of feathers.

steps.headline: Add more of the tiny tufts of the feathers all the way down towards the bottom.
steps.description: Try to make small patches rather than clumping them together.

steps.headline: Finish with some darkish clumps of feathers under the beak, and voila!
steps.description: You have a hawk! You can make a few last minute adjustments to your hawk, such as darkening certain clumps of feathers, or making the pupils larger.

text: Create a slight downward curve that sharply cuts up again at the bottom. This is the left side of the face. Use sketchy, scratched lines for this. Make a lower line for the bottom of the face. Use closer packed lines here. Continue upwards with a slight outward curve. Reconnect the lines after a slight curve over the top. Make a sharp V a little above the center of the head. This is your beak. Draw a line that curves slowly at first, then drops away. Use the same scratchy technique that you used with the lower part of the hawk. Add two dark holes on the top of either end of the beak.  Create an upside-down U over the holes and the beak, bringing a small line out from the right side of the beak.  Add a thick patch of lines along the right side. Have it slightly curve towards the beak. Add two eyes on either side of the beak. Add a few details to the beak. Create curving lines around the eyes and add a varying thickness to them. Then, on the left side, add some short thin lines to replicate tiny tufts of feathers. Add more of the tiny tufts of the feathers all the way down towards the bottom. Try to make small patches rather than clumping them together. Finish with some darkish clumps of feathers under the beak, and voila! You have a hawk! You can make a few last minute adjustments to your hawk, such as darkening certain clumps of feathers, or making the pupils larger.
